questions.title: What is the SOLID principle?
questions.content: The SOLID principles are a set of design principles in object-oriented programming aimed at making software designs more understandable, flexible, and maintainable.
questions.author: Derek

questions.title: How does version control work?
questions.content: Version control systems help manage changes to source code over time, allowing multiple developers to work on a project simultaneously.
questions.author: Eve

questions.title: What is continuous integration?
questions.content: Continuous integration (CI) is a practice in software development where code changes are automatically tested and integrated into the main codebase frequently.
questions.author: Frank

questions.title: What is microservices architecture?
questions.content: Microservices architecture is an approach to software development where an application is composed of small, independent services that communicate over a network.
questions.author: Grace

questions.title: What are design patterns?
questions.content: Design patterns are general, reusable solutions to common problems in software design.
questions.author: Hannah

questions.title: What is the purpose of unit testing?
questions.content: Unit testing involves testing individual units or components of a software to ensure they work as expected.
questions.author: Ian

questions.title: What is a RESTful API?
questions.content: A RESTful API is an API that adheres to the principles of Representational State Transfer (REST), allowing for interaction with web services using standard HTTP methods.
questions.author: Jack

questions.title: What is Agile methodology?
questions.content: Agile methodology is an iterative approach to software development that emphasizes flexibility, collaboration, and customer feedback.
questions.author: Karen

questions.title: How does a compiler differ from an interpreter?
questions.content: A compiler translates source code into machine code before execution, while an interpreter translates code line-by-line during execution.
questions.author: Leo

questions.title: What is dependency injection?
questions.content: Dependency injection is a design pattern in which an object's dependencies are provided to it, rather than the object creating them itself.
questions.author: Mia

questions.title: What are some common database normalization forms?
questions.content: Database normalization involves organizing tables to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity. Common forms include 1NF, 2NF, 3NF, and BCNF.
questions.author: Noah

questions.title: What is the difference between a thread and a process?
questions.content: A thread is the smallest unit of a process that can be scheduled, while a process is an independent executing instance of a program.
questions.author: Olivia

questions.title: What is the purpose of garbage collection in programming?
questions.content: Garbage collection is a form of automatic memory management that reclaims memory occupied by objects no longer in use.
questions.author: Paul

questions.title: What is a race condition?
questions.content: A race condition occurs when the behavior of a software system depends on the timing or order of uncontrollable events, leading to unpredictable outcomes.
questions.author: Quincy

questions.title: What is the Model-View-Controller (MVC) pattern?
questions.content: MVC is a design pattern that separates an application into three interconnected components: Model, View, and Controller.
questions.author: Rachel

questions.title: How does HTTP work?
questions.content: HTTP is a protocol used for transmitting data over the web, operating as a request-response protocol between a client and server.
questions.author: Steve

questions.title: What is the purpose of a load balancer?
questions.content: A load balancer distributes network or application traffic across multiple servers to ensure reliability and performance.
questions.author: Tina

questions.title: What is a deadlock in computing?
questions.content: A deadlock is a situation in a concurrent system where two or more processes are unable to proceed because each is waiting for the other to release a resource.
questions.author: Ulysses

questions.title: What is a software framework?
questions.content: A software framework is a platform for developing software applications, providing a foundation with predefined classes and functions.
questions.author: Victoria

questions.title: What is the difference between an abstract class and an interface?
questions.content: An abstract class can have method implementations and can be inherited from, while an interface only defines a contract and cannot have implementations.
questions.author: Walter

questions.title: What is the purpose of an API gateway?
questions.content: An API gateway acts as an entry point for API requests, handling routing, authentication, and other functions.
questions.author: Xena

questions.title: What are the different types of testing in software development?
questions.content: Types of testing include unit testing, integration testing, system testing, acceptance testing, performance testing, and more.
questions.author: Yvonne

questions.title: What is the purpose of a database index?
questions.content: A database index improves the speed of data retrieval operations on a database table by providing quick access to rows.
questions.author: Zach

questions.title: What is object-oriented programming (OOP)?
questions.content: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of objects, which contain data and methods.
questions.author: Aaron

questions.title: What is a singleton pattern?
questions.content: The singleton pattern ensures that a class has only one instance and provides a global point of access to it.
questions.author: Bella

questions.title: What is a callback function?
questions.content: A callback function is a function passed into another function as an argument, which is then invoked inside the outer function.
questions.author: Caleb

questions.title: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous programming?
questions.content: Synchronous programming executes tasks sequentially, while asynchronous programming allows tasks to be executed without waiting for other tasks to complete.
questions.author: Diana

questions.title: What is the purpose of a cache?
questions.content: A cache stores frequently accessed data to reduce the time needed to retrieve it from a slower data source.
questions.author: Edward

questions.title: What is the difference between SQL and NoSQL databases?
questions.content: SQL databases use structured query language and are relational, while NoSQL databases are non-relational and can store unstructured data.
questions.author: Fiona

questions.title: What is DevOps?
questions.content: DevOps is a set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) to shorten the development lifecycle.
questions.author: George
